trans-unit.source: Preparing your environment to back up Azure virtual machines | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Preparing your environment to back up Azure virtual machines | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Make sure your environment is prepared for backing up virtual machines in Azure
trans-unit.target: Make sure your environment is prepared for backing up virtual machines in Azure

trans-unit.source: Prepare your environment to back up Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Prepare your environment to back up Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Before you can back up an Azure virtual machine (VM), there are three conditions that must exist.
trans-unit.target: Before you can back up an Azure virtual machine (VM), there are three conditions that must exist.

trans-unit.source: You need to create a backup vault or identify an existing backup vault *in the same region as your VM*
trans-unit.target: You need to create a backup vault or identify an existing backup vault *in the same region as your VM*

trans-unit.source: Establish network connectivity between the Azure public Internet addresses and the Azure storage endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Establish network connectivity between the Azure public Internet addresses and the Azure storage endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Install the VM agent on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Install the VM agent on the VM.

trans-unit.source: If you know these conditions already exist in your environment then proceed to the [Back up your VMs article](backup-azure-vms.md).
trans-unit.target: If you know these conditions already exist in your environment then proceed to the [Back up your VMs article](backup-azure-vms.md).

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, read on, this article will lead you through the steps to prepare your environment to back up an Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, read on, this article will lead you through the steps to prepare your environment to back up an Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: Limitations when backing up and restoring a VM
trans-unit.target: Limitations when backing up and restoring a VM

trans-unit.source: Azure has two deployment models for creating and working with resources: [Resource Manager and classic](../resource-manager-deployment-model.md).
trans-unit.target: Azure has two deployment models for creating and working with resources: [Resource Manager and classic](../resource-manager-deployment-model.md).

trans-unit.source: The following list provides the limitations when deploying in the classic model.
trans-unit.target: The following list provides the limitations when deploying in the classic model.

trans-unit.source: Backing up Azure Resource Manager (ARM)-based (aka IaaS V2) virtual machines is not currently supported.
trans-unit.target: Backing up Azure Resource Manager (ARM)-based (aka IaaS V2) virtual machines is not currently supported.

trans-unit.source: Backing up virtual machines with more than 16 data disks is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Backing up virtual machines with more than 16 data disks is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Backing up virtual machines using Premium storage is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Backing up virtual machines using Premium storage is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Backing up virtual machines with a reserved IP address and no defined endpoint is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Backing up virtual machines with a reserved IP address and no defined endpoint is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Replacing an existing virtual machine during restore is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Replacing an existing virtual machine during restore is not supported.

trans-unit.source: First delete the existing virtual machine and any associated disks, and then restore the data from backup.
trans-unit.target: First delete the existing virtual machine and any associated disks, and then restore the data from backup.

trans-unit.source: Cross-region backup and restore is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Cross-region backup and restore is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Backing up virtual machines by using the Azure Backup service is supported in all public regions of Azure (see the [checklist](https://azure.microsoft.com/regions/#services) of supported regions).
trans-unit.target: Backing up virtual machines by using the Azure Backup service is supported in all public regions of Azure (see the [checklist](https://azure.microsoft.com/regions/#services) of supported regions).

trans-unit.source: If the region that you are looking for is unsupported today, it will not appear in the dropdown list during vault creation.
trans-unit.target: If the region that you are looking for is unsupported today, it will not appear in the dropdown list during vault creation.

trans-unit.source: Backing up virtual machines by using the Azure Backup service is supported only for select operating system versions:
trans-unit.target: Backing up virtual machines by using the Azure Backup service is supported only for select operating system versions:

trans-unit.source: **Linux**: See [the list of distributions that are endorsed by Azure](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-linux-endorsed-distros.md).
trans-unit.target: **Linux**: See [the list of distributions that are endorsed by Azure](../virtual-machines/virtual-machines-linux-endorsed-distros.md).

trans-unit.source: Other Bring-Your-Own-Linux distributions also should work as long as the VM agent is available on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Other Bring-Your-Own-Linux distributions also should work as long as the VM agent is available on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: **Windows Server**: Versions older than Windows Server 2008 R2 are not supported.
trans-unit.target: **Windows Server**: Versions older than Windows Server 2008 R2 are not supported.

trans-unit.source: Restoring a domain controller (DC) VM that is part of a multi-DC configuration is supported only through PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Restoring a domain controller (DC) VM that is part of a multi-DC configuration is supported only through PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Read more about [restoring a multi-DC domain controller](backup-azure-restore-vms.md#restoring-domain-controller-vms)
trans-unit.target: Read more about [restoring a multi-DC domain controller](backup-azure-restore-vms.md#restoring-domain-controller-vms)

trans-unit.source: Restoring virtual machines that have the following special network configurations is supported only through PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Restoring virtual machines that have the following special network configurations is supported only through PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: VMs that you create by using the restore workflow in the UI will not have these network configurations after the restore operation is complete.
trans-unit.target: VMs that you create by using the restore workflow in the UI will not have these network configurations after the restore operation is complete.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see [Restoring VMs with special network configurations](backup-azure-restore-vms.md#restoring-vms-with-special-netwrok-configurations)
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see [Restoring VMs with special network configurations](backup-azure-restore-vms.md#restoring-vms-with-special-netwrok-configurations)

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines under load balancer configuration (internal and external)
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines under load balancer configuration (internal and external)

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines with multiple reserved IP addresses
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines with multiple reserved IP addresses

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines with multiple network adapters
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines with multiple network adapters

trans-unit.source: Create a backup vault for a VM
trans-unit.target: Create a backup vault for a VM

trans-unit.source: A backup vault is an entity that stores all the backups and recovery points that have been created over time.
trans-unit.target: A backup vault is an entity that stores all the backups and recovery points that have been created over time.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault also contains the backup policies that will be applied to the virtual machines being backed up.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault also contains the backup policies that will be applied to the virtual machines being backed up.

trans-unit.source: This image shows the relationships between the various Azure Backup entities:
trans-unit.target: This image shows the relationships between the various Azure Backup entities:

trans-unit.source: Azure Backup entities and relationships
trans-unit.target: Azure Backup entities and relationships

trans-unit.source: To create a backup vault:
trans-unit.target: To create a backup vault:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com/)
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com/)

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal click **New** > **Hybrid Integration** > **Backup**.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal click **New** > **Hybrid Integration** > **Backup**.

trans-unit.source: When you click **Backup**, you will automatically switch to the classic portal (shown after the Note).
trans-unit.target: When you click **Backup**, you will automatically switch to the classic portal (shown after the Note).

trans-unit.source: Ibiza portal
trans-unit.target: Ibiza portal

trans-unit.source: If your subscription was last used in the classic portal, then your subscription may open in the classic portal.
trans-unit.target: If your subscription was last used in the classic portal, then your subscription may open in the classic portal.

trans-unit.source: In this event, to create a backup vault, click **New** > **Data Services** > **Recovery Services** > **Backup Vault** > **Quick Create** (see the image below).
trans-unit.target: In this event, to create a backup vault, click **New** > **Data Services** > **Recovery Services** > **Backup Vault** > **Quick Create** (see the image below).

trans-unit.source: Create backup vault
trans-unit.target: Create backup vault

trans-unit.source: For **Name**, enter a friendly name to identify the vault.
trans-unit.target: For **Name**, enter a friendly name to identify the vault.

trans-unit.source: The name needs to be unique for the Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The name needs to be unique for the Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Type a name that contains between 2 and 50 characters.
trans-unit.target: Type a name that contains between 2 and 50 characters.

trans-unit.source: It must start with a letter, and can contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.
trans-unit.target: It must start with a letter, and can contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.

trans-unit.source: In **Region**, select the geographic region for the vault.
trans-unit.target: In **Region**, select the geographic region for the vault.

trans-unit.source: The vault must be in the same region as the virtual machines that you want to protect.
trans-unit.target: The vault must be in the same region as the virtual machines that you want to protect.

trans-unit.source: If you have virtual machines in multiple regions, you must create a backup vault in each region.
trans-unit.target: If you have virtual machines in multiple regions, you must create a backup vault in each region.

trans-unit.source: There is no need to specify storage accounts to store the backup data--the backup vault and the Azure Backup service handle this automatically.
trans-unit.target: There is no need to specify storage accounts to store the backup data--the backup vault and the Azure Backup service handle this automatically.

trans-unit.source: In **Subscription** select the subscription you want to associate with the backup vault.
trans-unit.target: In **Subscription** select the subscription you want to associate with the backup vault.

trans-unit.source: There will be multiple choices only if your organizational account is associated with multiple Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: There will be multiple choices only if your organizational account is associated with multiple Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create Vault**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create Vault**.

trans-unit.source: It can take a while for the backup vault to be created.
trans-unit.target: It can take a while for the backup vault to be created.

trans-unit.source: Monitor the status notifications at the bottom of the portal.
trans-unit.target: Monitor the status notifications at the bottom of the portal.

trans-unit.source: Create vault toast notification
trans-unit.target: Create vault toast notification

trans-unit.source: A message will confirm that the vault has been successfully created.
trans-unit.target: A message will confirm that the vault has been successfully created.

trans-unit.source: It will be listed on the **recovery services** page as **Active**.
trans-unit.target: It will be listed on the **recovery services** page as **Active**.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to choose the appropriate storage redundancy option right after the vault has been created.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to choose the appropriate storage redundancy option right after the vault has been created.

trans-unit.source: Read more about [setting the storage redundancy option in the backup vault](backup-configure-vault.md#azure-backup---storage-redundancy-options)
trans-unit.target: Read more about [setting the storage redundancy option in the backup vault](backup-configure-vault.md#azure-backup---storage-redundancy-options)

trans-unit.source: List of backup vaults
trans-unit.target: List of backup vaults

trans-unit.source: Click the backup vault to go to the **Quick Start** page, where the instructions for backing up Azure virtual machines are shown.
trans-unit.target: Click the backup vault to go to the **Quick Start** page, where the instructions for backing up Azure virtual machines are shown.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machine backup instructions on the Dashboard page
trans-unit.target: Virtual machine backup instructions on the Dashboard page

trans-unit.source: Network connectivity
trans-unit.target: Network connectivity

trans-unit.source: The backup extension needs connectivity to the Azure public IP addresses to function correctly because it sends commands to an Azure Storage endpoint (HTTP URL) to manage the snapshots of the VM.
trans-unit.target: The backup extension needs connectivity to the Azure public IP addresses to function correctly because it sends commands to an Azure Storage endpoint (HTTP URL) to manage the snapshots of the VM.

trans-unit.source: Without the right Internet connectivity, these HTTP requests from the VM will time out and the backup operation will fail.
trans-unit.target: Without the right Internet connectivity, these HTTP requests from the VM will time out and the backup operation will fail.

trans-unit.source: Network restrictions with NSGs
trans-unit.target: Network restrictions with NSGs

trans-unit.source: If your deployment has access restrictions in place (through a network security group (NSG), for example), then you need to take additional steps to ensure that backup traffic to the backup vault remains unaffected.
trans-unit.target: If your deployment has access restrictions in place (through a network security group (NSG), for example), then you need to take additional steps to ensure that backup traffic to the backup vault remains unaffected.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to provide a path for the backup traffic:
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to provide a path for the backup traffic:

trans-unit.source: Whitelist the [Azure datacenter IP ranges](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=41653)
trans-unit.target: Whitelist the [Azure datacenter IP ranges](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=41653)

trans-unit.source: Deploy an HTTP proxy to route the traffic.
trans-unit.target: Deploy an HTTP proxy to route the traffic.

trans-unit.source: The trade-off is between manageability, granular control, and cost.
trans-unit.target: The trade-off is between manageability, granular control, and cost.

trans-unit.source: Option
trans-unit.target: Option

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: Disadvantages
trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: OPTION 1: Whitelist IP ranges
trans-unit.target: OPTION 1: Whitelist IP ranges

trans-unit.source: No additional costs.
trans-unit.target: No additional costs.

trans-unit.source: For opening access in an NSG, use the Set-AzureNetworkSecurityRule cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: For opening access in an NSG, use the Set-AzureNetworkSecurityRule cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Complex to manage as the impacted IP ranges change over time.
trans-unit.target: Complex to manage as the impacted IP ranges change over time.

trans-unit.source: Provides access to the whole of Azure, and not just Storage.
trans-unit.target: Provides access to the whole of Azure, and not just Storage.

trans-unit.source: OPTION 2: HTTP proxy
trans-unit.target: OPTION 2: HTTP proxy

trans-unit.source: Granular control in the proxy over the storage URLs allowed.
trans-unit.target: Granular control in the proxy over the storage URLs allowed.

trans-unit.source: Single point of Internet access to VMs.
trans-unit.target: Single point of Internet access to VMs.

trans-unit.source: Not subject to Azure IP address changes.
trans-unit.target: Not subject to Azure IP address changes.

trans-unit.source: Additional costs for running a VM with the proxy software.
trans-unit.target: Additional costs for running a VM with the proxy software.

trans-unit.source: Using an HTTP proxy for VM backups
trans-unit.target: Using an HTTP proxy for VM backups

trans-unit.source: When backing up a VM, the snapshot management commands are sent from the backup extension to Azure Storage using an HTTPS API.
trans-unit.target: When backing up a VM, the snapshot management commands are sent from the backup extension to Azure Storage using an HTTPS API.

trans-unit.source: This traffic must be routed from the extension through the proxy, since only the proxy will be configured to have access to the public Internet.
trans-unit.target: This traffic must be routed from the extension through the proxy, since only the proxy will be configured to have access to the public Internet.

trans-unit.source: There is no recommendation for the proxy software that should be used.
trans-unit.target: There is no recommendation for the proxy software that should be used.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you pick a proxy that is compatible with the configuration steps below.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you pick a proxy that is compatible with the configuration steps below.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the App VM needs to be configured to use the Proxy VM for all HTTP traffic bound for the public Internet.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the App VM needs to be configured to use the Proxy VM for all HTTP traffic bound for the public Internet.

trans-unit.source: The Proxy VM needs to be configured to allow incoming traffic from VMs in the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: The Proxy VM needs to be configured to allow incoming traffic from VMs in the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: And finally, the NSG (named *NSG-lockdown*) needs a new security rule that allows outbound Internet traffic from the Proxy VM.
trans-unit.target: And finally, the NSG (named *NSG-lockdown*) needs a new security rule that allows outbound Internet traffic from the Proxy VM.

trans-unit.source: NSG with HTTP proxy deployment diagram
trans-unit.target: NSG with HTTP proxy deployment diagram

trans-unit.source: A) Allow outgoing network connections:
trans-unit.target: A) Allow outgoing network connections:

trans-unit.source: For Windows machines, run the following command in an elevated command prompt:
trans-unit.target: For Windows machines, run the following command in an elevated command prompt:

trans-unit.source: This will set up a machine-wide proxy configuration, and will be used for any outgoing HTTP/HTTPS traffic.
trans-unit.target: This will set up a machine-wide proxy configuration, and will be used for any outgoing HTTP/HTTPS traffic.

trans-unit.source: For Linux machines, add the following line to the ```/etc/environment``` file:
trans-unit.target: For Linux machines, add the following line to the ```/etc/environment``` file:

trans-unit.source: Add the following lines to the ```/etc/waagent.conf``` file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following lines to the ```/etc/waagent.conf``` file:

trans-unit.source: B) Allow incoming connections on the proxy server:
trans-unit.target: B) Allow incoming connections on the proxy server:

trans-unit.source: On the proxy server, open Windows Firewall.
trans-unit.target: On the proxy server, open Windows Firewall.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to access the firewall is to search for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to access the firewall is to search for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

trans-unit.source: Open the Firewall
trans-unit.target: Open the Firewall

trans-unit.source: In the Windows Firewall dialog, right-click **Inbound Rules** and click **New Rule...**
trans-unit.target: In the Windows Firewall dialog, right-click **Inbound Rules** and click **New Rule...**

trans-unit.source: Create a new rule
trans-unit.target: Create a new rule

trans-unit.source: In the **New Inbound Rule Wizard**, choose the **Custom** option for the **Rule Type** and click **Next**
trans-unit.target: In the **New Inbound Rule Wizard**, choose the **Custom** option for the **Rule Type** and click **Next**

trans-unit.source: On the page to select the **Program**, choose **All Programs** and click **Next**
trans-unit.target: On the page to select the **Program**, choose **All Programs** and click **Next**

trans-unit.source: On the **Protocol and Ports** page, enter the following information and click **Next**:
trans-unit.target: On the **Protocol and Ports** page, enter the following information and click **Next**:

trans-unit.source: Create a new rule
trans-unit.target: Create a new rule

trans-unit.source: for *Protocol type* choose *TCP*
trans-unit.target: for *Protocol type* choose *TCP*

trans-unit.source: for *Local port* choose *Specific Ports*, in the field below specify the ```<Proxy Port>``` that has been configured.
trans-unit.target: for *Local port* choose *Specific Ports*, in the field below specify the ```<Proxy Port>``` that has been configured.

trans-unit.source: for *Remote port* select *All Ports*
trans-unit.target: for *Remote port* select *All Ports*

trans-unit.source: For the rest of the wizard, click all the way to the end and give this rule a name.
trans-unit.target: For the rest of the wizard, click all the way to the end and give this rule a name.

trans-unit.source: C) Add an exception rule to the NSG:
trans-unit.target: C) Add an exception rule to the NSG:

trans-unit.source: In an Azure PowerShell command prompt, type out the following command:
trans-unit.target: In an Azure PowerShell command prompt, type out the following command:

trans-unit.source: This command adds an exception to the NSG, which allows TCP traffic from any port on 10.0.0.5 to any Internet address on port 80 (HTTP) or 443 (HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: This command adds an exception to the NSG, which allows TCP traffic from any port on 10.0.0.5 to any Internet address on port 80 (HTTP) or 443 (HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: If you need to hit a specific port in the public Internet, make sure that you add that to the ```-DestinationPortRange``` as well.
trans-unit.target: If you need to hit a specific port in the public Internet, make sure that you add that to the ```-DestinationPortRange``` as well.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you replace the names in the example with the details appropriate to your deployment.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you replace the names in the example with the details appropriate to your deployment.

trans-unit.source: VM agent
trans-unit.target: VM agent

trans-unit.source: Before you can back up the Azure virtual machine, you should ensure that the Azure VM agent is correctly installed on the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Before you can back up the Azure virtual machine, you should ensure that the Azure VM agent is correctly installed on the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Since the VM agent is an optional component at the time that the virtual machine is created, ensure that the check box for the VM agent is selected before the virtual machine is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: Since the VM agent is an optional component at the time that the virtual machine is created, ensure that the check box for the VM agent is selected before the virtual machine is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Manual installation and update
trans-unit.target: Manual installation and update

trans-unit.source: The VM agent is already present in VMs that are created from the Azure gallery.
trans-unit.target: The VM agent is already present in VMs that are created from the Azure gallery.

trans-unit.source: However, virtual machines that are migrated from on-premises datacenters would not have the VM agent installed.
trans-unit.target: However, virtual machines that are migrated from on-premises datacenters would not have the VM agent installed.

trans-unit.source: For such VMs, the VM agent needs to be installed explicitly.
trans-unit.target: For such VMs, the VM agent needs to be installed explicitly.

trans-unit.source: Read more about [installing the VM agent on an existing VM](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx)
trans-unit.target: Read more about [installing the VM agent on an existing VM](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx)

trans-unit.source: Operation
trans-unit.target: Operation

trans-unit.source: Windows
trans-unit.target: Windows

trans-unit.source: Linux
trans-unit.target: Linux

trans-unit.source: Installing the VM agent
trans-unit.target: Installing the VM agent

trans-unit.source: Download and install the [agent MSI](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409).
trans-unit.target: Download and install the [agent MSI](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409).

trans-unit.source: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.
trans-unit.target: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.

trans-unit.source: Install the latest [Linux agent](https://github.com/Azure/WALinuxAgent) from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Install the latest [Linux agent](https://github.com/Azure/WALinuxAgent) from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: You will need Administrator privileges to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.
trans-unit.target: [Update the VM property](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mast/archive/2014/04/08/install-the-vm-agent-on-an-existing-azure-vm.aspx) to indicate that the agent is installed.

trans-unit.source: Updating the VM agent
trans-unit.target: Updating the VM agent

trans-unit.source: Updating the VM agent is as simple as reinstalling the [VM agent binaries](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409)
trans-unit.target: Updating the VM agent is as simple as reinstalling the [VM agent binaries](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394789&clcid=0x409)

trans-unit.source: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM agent is being updated.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM agent is being updated.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions on [updating the Linux VM agent ](../virtual-machines-linux-update-agent.md)
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions on [updating the Linux VM agent ](../virtual-machines-linux-update-agent.md)

trans-unit.source: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM agent is being updated.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that no backup operation is running while the VM agent is being updated.

trans-unit.source: Validating the VM agent installation
trans-unit.target: Validating the VM agent installation

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the *C:\WindowsAzure\Packages* folder in the Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the *C:\WindowsAzure\Packages* folder in the Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: You should find the WaAppAgent.exe file present.
trans-unit.target: You should find the WaAppAgent.exe file present.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the file, go to **Properties**, and then select the **Details** tab.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the file, go to **Properties**, and then select the **Details** tab.

trans-unit.source: The Product Version field should be 2.6.1198.718 or higher.
trans-unit.target: The Product Version field should be 2.6.1198.718 or higher.

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: Learn about the [VM agent](https://go.microsoft.com/fwLink/?LinkID=390493&clcid=0x409) and [how to install it](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/04/15/vm-agent-and-extensions-part-2/)
trans-unit.target: Learn about the [VM agent](https://go.microsoft.com/fwLink/?LinkID=390493&clcid=0x409) and [how to install it](https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/04/15/vm-agent-and-extensions-part-2/)

trans-unit.source: Backup extension
trans-unit.target: Backup extension

trans-unit.source: To back up the virtual machine, the Azure Backup service installs an extension to the VM agent.
trans-unit.target: To back up the virtual machine, the Azure Backup service installs an extension to the VM agent.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Backup service seamlessly upgrades and patches the backup extension without additional user intervention.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Backup service seamlessly upgrades and patches the backup extension without additional user intervention.

trans-unit.source: The backup extension is installed if the VM is running.
trans-unit.target: The backup extension is installed if the VM is running.

trans-unit.source: A running VM also provides the greatest chance of getting an application-consistent recovery point.
trans-unit.target: A running VM also provides the greatest chance of getting an application-consistent recovery point.

trans-unit.source: However, the Azure Backup service will continue to back up the VM--even if it is turned off, and the extension could not be installed (aka Offline VM).
trans-unit.target: However, the Azure Backup service will continue to back up the VM--even if it is turned off, and the extension could not be installed (aka Offline VM).

trans-unit.source: In this case, the recovery point will be *crash consistent* as discussed above.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the recovery point will be *crash consistent* as discussed above.

trans-unit.source: Questions?
trans-unit.target: Questions?

trans-unit.source: If you have questions, or if there is any feature that you would like to see included, [send us feedback](http://aka.ms/azurebackup_feedback)

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you have prepared your environment for backing up your VM, your next logical step is to create a backup.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have prepared your environment for backing up your VM, your next logical step is to create a backup.

trans-unit.source: The planning article provides more detailed information about backing up VMs.
trans-unit.target: The planning article provides more detailed information about backing up VMs.
